[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult] [Type Safety] Can a malicious native function implementation return inconsistent NativeResult variants that cause the VM to misinterpret execution outcomes, potentially leading to state corruption or incorrect gas charging? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::Success] [Resource Safety] Can a native function return Success with ret_vals containing invalid Value types that violate Move's resource safety guarantees, allowing double-spending of resources or resource duplication? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::Success] [Gas Manipulation] Can a malicious native function return Success with artificially low cost values, allowing attackers to execute expensive operations while paying minimal gas fees, enabling DoS attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::Success] [Return Value Manipulation] Can a native function return Success with more or fewer ret_vals than expected by the calling Move code, causing stack corruption or type confusion in the VM? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::Abort] [Abort Code Manipulation] Can a malicious native function use carefully crafted abort_code values to bypass error handling logic or trigger unintended code paths in the calling contract, leading to fund loss? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::Abort] [Gas Undercharging] Can a native function abort after performing expensive operations but report minimal cost, allowing attackers to exhaust validator resources without paying appropriate gas fees? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::OutOfGas] [Gas Metering Bypass] Can a native function return OutOfGas with partial_cost set to zero or negative values (via integer underflow), bypassing gas accounting and enabling unlimited computation? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::OutOfGas] [State Inconsistency] If a native function returns OutOfGas after partially modifying VM state, can this lead to inconsistent state across validators, potentially causing consensus failures or double-spending? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::OutOfGas] [Incremental Metering Exploit] Can attackers exploit the incremental gas metering feature by repeatedly calling natives that return OutOfGas to probe the remaining gas balance and optimize attacks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::CallFunction] [Control Flow Hijacking] Can a malicious native function use CallFunction to jump to arbitrary functions outside the intended call graph, bypassing access controls or executing privileged operations? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::CallFunction] [Module Confusion] Can CallFunction be exploited to call functions from system modules (like 0x1::coin or 0x1::aptos_governance) with attacker-controlled arguments, leading to unauthorized minting or governance manipulation? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::CallFunction] [Type Argument Injection] Can a native function manipulate ty_args in CallFunction to pass incorrect type arguments to the target function, bypassing type safety and potentially accessing resources of the wrong type? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::CallFunction] [Argument Count Mismatch] Does the VM properly validate that the args vector matches the target function's expected parameter count and types, or can mismatched arguments cause stack corruption? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::CallFunction] [Calling Convention Violation] The documentation states the calling convention requires matching type signatures except for an extra dispatch argument - can violating this convention in paranoid mode be exploited to bypass security checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::CallFunction] [Recursion Attack] Can CallFunction be used to create unbounded recursion chains that bypass stack depth limits, causing validator crashes or resource exhaustion? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::CallFunction] [Gas Cost Inconsistency] Can natives report low cost for CallFunction while the dispatched function performs expensive operations, leading to gas undercharging and DoS vulnerabilities? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::LoadModule] [Module Loading Exploit] Can a malicious native trigger LoadModule for untrusted or malicious modules, causing the VM to load and execute unverified bytecode? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::LoadModule] [Dependency Charging Bypass] Can attackers exploit LoadModule to load many modules without proper dependency cost charging, exhausting validator memory and storage? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Enum: NativeResult::LoadModule] [Module Confusion Attack] Can LoadModule be used to reload already-loaded modules with different versions or contents, causing inconsistent execution across validators? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Function: NativeResult::ok()] [Integer Overflow] Can the cost parameter in ok() overflow InternalGas type limits, causing incorrect gas accounting or negative gas charges? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Function: NativeResult::ok()] [SmallVec Exploitation] Can an attacker cause ok() to receive a values SmallVec larger than expected, triggering heap allocation and potential memory exhaustion attacks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Function: NativeResult::ok()] [Return Value Poisoning] Can malicious natives call ok() with Values that contain invalid internal state (e.g., corrupted resource handles), which then get propagated to other transactions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Function: NativeResult::ok()] [Zero-Cost Success] Can natives call ok() with zero cost after performing expensive operations, bypassing gas metering entirely? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Function: NativeResult::err()] [Abort Code Injection] Can an attacker manipulate the abort_code parameter in err() to match specific error codes used by critical system modules, causing misinterpretation of errors and bypassing safety checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/types/src/natives/function.rs] [Function: NativeResult::err()] [Cost Manipulation on Failure] Can natives report artificially high costs in err() to drain gas from transactions without actually performing work, griefing users? (Medium)
